title: FirstFT: Hawkish Fed shakes investors
text:
Equity markets in Asia and Europe are taking their direction today from a late sell-off on Wall Street after the US Federal Reserve signalled it would begin raising interest rates from March to control rampant inflation.

Speaking after the first meeting this year of the interest rate setting Federal Open Market Committee, chair Jay Powell said the US central bank had “quite a bit of room to raise interest rates without threatening the labour market”.

Inflation hit an annual rate of 7 per cent in December — well above the Fed's 2 per cent target — and the unemployment rate has fallen to 3.9 per cent after peaking at nearly 15 per cent at the beginning of the pandemic.

Powell declined to say how many rate rises there would be this year. He also would not be drawn on whether the Fed would consider raising rates from their current near-zero level by half a percentage point at some point this year, as opposed to the quarter point increases that have become the norm. It is more than two decades since the central bank last raised rates by more than 0.25 per cent.

He highlighted the current strength of the economy in comments to journalists after the FOMC meeting, compared with previous rate tightening cycles.

“If you look back to . . . 2015, 16, 17, 18, when we were raising rates, inflation was very close to 2 per cent, even below,” he said.

Eric Winograd, senior economist at AllianceBernstein, characterised Powell's comments as “very hawkish”.

Investors agreed. The benchmark S&P 500 closed down 0.1 per cent, reversing earlier gains of as much as 3.4 per cent, the biggest downward turn for the index since September 2020.

The Nasdaq Composite index also ended the day unchanged, having been up more than 3 per cent before the Powell press conference. Equity markets in Europe and Asia were lower today and US futures trading suggested further losses for equity markets when Wall Street opens later.

In the debt markets, the biggest moves were in the rate sensitive two-year Treasury bond market. The yield on the two-year Treasury note climbed to 1.16 per cent — its highest level since February 2020. The yield on the 10-year note rose 0.09 percentage points to 1.87 per cent. Bond yields rise when prices fall.

  • Opinion: By abandoning a systemic framework for monetary policy, the central bank has spawned an all-asset speculative bubble, writes John Hussman.

Has the Fed made a policy error? Do investors have reason to worry? Share your thoughts with us at firstft@ft.com. Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. West commits to keeping Nato open to new members The US and Nato told Moscow yesterday they were committed to keeping the transatlantic alliance open to new members, rebuffing a central Russian security demand that could determine the outcome of the Ukraine crisis. “Nato's door is open, remains open and that remains our commitment,” Antony Blinken, US secretary of state, said.

  • Sanctions news: The European Central Bank has warned lenders with exposure to Russia to prepare for international sanctions in case of an invasion.

2. Bill Ackman buys Netflix stake worth $1.1bn Pershing Square, Bill Ackman's investment group, has bought 3.1m shares of Netflix in recent days as the hedge fund billionaire seeks to capitalise on a sharp sell-off that has almost halved the streaming company's market value in the past few months.

3. Facebook gives up on digital payments ambitions The Facebook-led Diem cryptocurrency project is preparing to sell its assets, as the social media giant admits defeat in its once-sprawling digital payments ambitions. The Diem Association, which was launched by Facebook in 2019, is planning to wind down, according to several people familiar with the discussions.

4. Stephen Breyer plans to retire from US Supreme Court The senior liberal justice plans to retire this year, according to media reports, a move that would pose a political test for President Joe Biden as he seeks to install a progressive replacement. The Supreme Court's oldest member has come under mounting pressure in recent months to step down, allowing Biden to nominate a younger liberal to fill his seat.

5. Prince Andrew seeks trial by jury in US case The British royal has asked a New York judge for a trial by jury as he once again denied allegations of sexually abusing one of the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein's accusers. In court documents filed yesterday, he admitted meeting Epstein in or around 1999 but denied claims by Virginia Roberts Giuffre that he sexually abused her.

Keep up with the news throughout the day with Top Stories Today, a short-form audio digest of headlines. Find the latest episode here.

Coronavirus digest

  • Chinese government officials have tightened Covid-19 restrictions in parts of Beijing, as the country steps up efforts to prevent any disruption to the Winter Olympics next month.

  • Bank of America is examining relocating staff from Hong Kong to Singapore because of the severe pandemic restrictions in the Chinese territory.

  • The largest international business group in Japan has warned that the country's tight border restrictions risk staunching foreign investment and crushing Tokyo's efforts to compete as a global financial centre.

  • Tesla reported a record $2.3bn net profit for the fourth quarter of 2021 but warned supply constraints would weigh on its results “through 2022”.

  • American Express said robust spending across its card network suggested its customers were adapting to the “reality of the pandemic”.

  • Supply chain bottlenecks and weak household spending have turned Germany from Europe's economic locomotive into its laggard.

The day ahead

US fourth-quarter GDP The US economy is forecast to have grown solidly in the fourth quarter but gross domestic product data will not capture the full impact of the Omicron variant.

Apple earnings The world's most valuable company reports after the market closes. Yesterday it reclaimed the top smartphone seller spot in China for the first time in six years. Here's what to look out for in the results. Also reporting today are McDonald's, Southwest Airlines, Altria and Mondelez.

Honduras's new president Xiomara Castro will be sworn in as the nation's first female president after a landslide victory in November.

International Holocaust Remembrance Day Today marks the 77th anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi German concentration camp Auschwitz. Earlier this month, the FT's Sarah Ebner reflected on her experience obtaining a European passport after Austrian citizenship was restored to families of Nazi victims.

What else we're reading and watching

Has appetite for plant-based meat peaked? Consumer interest in plant-based meats surged around the flotation of US start-up Beyond Meat in 2019. But sales growth is falling in the US and the UK. Investment is continuing, with $3bn raised in 2021 — but are products failing to meet taste expectations?

BlackRock's active strategies BlackRock's stockpickers are accustomed to toiling in the shadow of the group's exchange-traded fund business, which sucked in more than $1bn a day on average last year from investors. While passive funds still dominate the show, efforts to revive its actively-managed funds are beginning to pay off.

International investors in Chinese companies face growing risks As property companies such as Evergrande teeter on the brink of collapse and Beijing cracks down on the tech sector, are the opportunities to make money worth the growing political risk? The FT's global China editor James Kynge and markets editor Katie Martin discuss.

San Francisco is scaring away the tech crowd As a failure to tackle the epidemic of poverty continues, start-up founders, engineers and venture capitalists are leaving the city. If it wants its tech crown back it cannot afford to just continue as normal, writes Hannah Murphy.

Who is Bola Ahmed Tinubu, the ‘godfather' of Lagos? The 69-year-old has solidified his status as the most powerful man in the commercial engine of Africa's largest economy. But his success also made clear the challenges he faces as he runs for Nigeria's presidency in 2023: his age in a country where almost two-thirds are under 24.

Work and careers

Hybrid work is polarising. But why? In this episode of the Working It podcast, Isabel Berwick talks to Camilla Cavendish and Pilita Clark about the most divisive topic in workplaces: whether it is time to put an end to homeworking.
